**The Library of Trinity College Dublin** serves [Trinity
College](/wiki/Trinity_College,_Dublin "Trinity College, Dublin") and the
[University of Dublin](/wiki/University_of_Dublin "University of Dublin"). It
is the largest [library](/wiki/Library "Library") in [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland
"Ireland") and, as a [legal deposit](/wiki/Legal_deposit "Legal deposit") or
"copyright library", it has rights to receive material published in the
[Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") free of
charge; it is also the only Irish library to hold such rights for the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"). The Library is the permanent
home to the famous [Book of Kells](/wiki/Book_of_Kells "Book of Kells"). Two
of the four volumes are on public display, one opened to a major decorated
page and the other to a typical page of text. The volumes and pages shown are
regularly changed.[2] Members of the University of Dublin also have access to
the libraries of [Tallaght Hospital](/wiki/Tallaght_Hospital "Tallaght
Hospital") and the [Irish School of Ecumenics](/wiki/Irish_School_of_Ecumenics
"Irish School of Ecumenics"), [Milltown](/wiki/Milltown,_Dublin "Milltown,
Dublin").

## Constituent Library
buildings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trinity_College_Library&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Constituent Library buildings")]

The Library proper occupies several buildings, four of which are at the
Trinity College campus itself, with another part of the Trinity Centre at [St.
James's Hospital](/wiki/St._James%27s_Hospital "St. James's Hospital"),
[Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin"):

  * The original (Old) Library is [Thomas Burgh](/wiki/Thomas_Burgh_\(1670-1730\) "Thomas Burgh \(1670-1730\)")’s masterpiece. A huge building, it originally towered over the university and city after its completion. Even today, surrounded by similarly scaled buildings, it is imposing and dominates the view of the university from Nassau Street. The Book of Kells is located in the Old Library, along with the [Book of Durrow](/wiki/Book_of_Durrow "Book of Durrow"), the [Book of Howth](/wiki/Book_of_Howth "Book of Howth") and other ancient texts. Also incorporating the Long Room, the Old Library is one of Ireland's biggest tourist attractions, and holds thousands of rare, and in many cases very early, volumes. In the 18th century, the college received the [Brian Boru harp](/wiki/Trinity_College_Harp "Trinity College Harp"), one of the three surviving medieval Gaelic harps, and a national symbol of Ireland, which is now housed in the Library. Housed within the Old Library are: 
    * Early Printed Books and Special Collections
    * Manuscripts & Archives Research Library (M&ARL)
  * The Berkeley/Lecky/Ussher (BLU) Arts Libraries complex, incorporating: 
    * The [Berkeley](/wiki/Bishop_Berkeley "Bishop Berkeley") Library, in Fellows Square
    * The [Lecky](/wiki/William_Edward_Hartpole_Lecky "William Edward Hartpole Lecky") Library, attached to the Arts Building
    * The [Ussher](/wiki/James_Ussher "James Ussher") Library, overlooking [College Park](/wiki/College_Park,_Dublin "College Park, Dublin")
    * The Glucksman Map Library
    * The Preservation and Conservation Department
  * The [Hamilton](/wiki/William_Rowan_Hamilton "William Rowan Hamilton") Science and Engineering Library
  * The 1937 Reading Room (for graduate use)
  * The [John Stearne](/wiki/John_Stearne_\(physician\) "John Stearne \(physician\)") Medical Library (JSML), housed at St James's Hospital

Further materials are held in storage in Stacks, either in closed access
within College or at a book depository in the Dublin suburb of
[Santry](/wiki/Santry "Santry").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trinity_College_Library&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

The Library began with the founding of Trinity College in 1592. In 1661,
[Henry Jones](/wiki/Henry_Jones_\(bishop\) "Henry Jones \(bishop\)") presented
it with the Book of Kells, its most famous manuscript. [James
Ussher](/wiki/James_Ussher "James Ussher") (1625–56), Archbishop of Armagh,
whose most important works were _" Veterum Epistolarum Hibernicarum Sylloge"_
(1632) and _" Brittanicarum Ecclesiarum Antiquitates"_ (1639), left his
valuable library, comprising several thousand printed books and manuscripts,
to the Library. His complete works were published by the Library in twenty-
four volumes.[3]

In 1801, the Library was given [legal deposit](/wiki/Legal_deposit "Legal
deposit") rights, making it the only library in Ireland to have such rights
for the United Kingdom at that time.[3] Starting at 4 pm on Saturday 29
November 2009, the Trinity Students' Union organized a 24-hour sit-in in
protest at a reduced book-buying budget, lack of access to books on Sundays,
and a proposed reduction of counter services.[4]

## Legal deposit library
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trinity_College_Library&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Legal deposit library status")]

According to the [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of
Ireland")'s Copyright and Related Rights Act, 2000, the Library is entitled,
along with the [National Library of Ireland](/wiki/National_Library_of_Ireland
"National Library of Ireland") and the libraries of the [National University
of Ireland](/wiki/National_University_of_Ireland "National University of
Ireland"), the [University of Limerick](/wiki/University_of_Limerick
"University of Limerick"), and [Dublin City
University](/wiki/Dublin_City_University "Dublin City University"), to receive
a copy of all works published in the Republic of Ireland. Also, as a result of
the [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") [Legal Deposit Libraries
Act 2003](/wiki/Legal_Deposit_Libraries_Act_2003 "Legal Deposit Libraries Act
2003"), which continues a more ancient right dating from 1801, the Library is
entitled, along with the [British Library](/wiki/British_Library "British
Library"), the [Bodleian Library](/wiki/Bodleian_Library "Bodleian Library")
at [Oxford](/wiki/Oxford "Oxford"), [Cambridge University
Library](/wiki/Cambridge_University_Library "Cambridge University Library"),
the [National Library of Wales](/wiki/National_Library_of_Wales "National
Library of Wales") and the [National Library of
Scotland](/wiki/National_Library_of_Scotland "National Library of Scotland"),
to receive a copy on request of all works published in the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom").

## The Long
Room[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trinity_College_Library&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: The Long Room")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/County_Dublin_-
_Long_Room-Trinity_College_-_20180703092642.jpg/220px-County_Dublin_-
_Long_Room-Trinity_College_-_20180703092642.jpg)](/wiki/File:County_Dublin_-
_Long_Room-Trinity_College_-_20180703092642.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:County_Dublin_-_Long_Room-Trinity_College_-_20180703092642.jpg
"Enlarge")

Detail of Long Room shelving

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/James_Malton_Trinity_College_Library_Dublin.jpg/220px-
James_Malton_Trinity_College_Library_Dublin.jpg)](/wiki/File:James_Malton_Trinity_College_Library_Dublin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:James_Malton_Trinity_College_Library_Dublin.jpg "Enlarge")

Watercolour of Long Room before the roof was raised

The 65-metre-long (213 ft) main chamber of the Old Library, the Long Room, was
built between 1712 and 1732 and houses 200,000 of the Library's oldest books.
Initially The Long Room had a flat ceiling, shelving for books only on the
lower level, and an open gallery. By the 1850s the room had to be expanded as
the shelves were filled due to the fact that the Library had been given
permission to obtain a free copy of every book that had been published in
[Ireland and Britain](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland
"United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland"). In 1860, The Long Room's roof
was raised to accommodate an upper gallery.[5] The Long Room is lined with
marble busts. The marble bust collection was formed when 14 busts from the
famous sculptor [Peter Scheemakers](/wiki/Peter_Scheemakers "Peter
Scheemakers") were acquired by the college. Many of the busts are of great
philosophers, writers, and men who supported the college. The most outstanding
bust in the collection is of the writer [Jonathan Swift](/wiki/Jonathan_Swift
"Jonathan Swift"), created by [Louis François
Roubiliac](/wiki/Louis_Fran%C3%A7ois_Roubiliac "Louis François Roubiliac").[5]

The Long Room also holds one of the last remaining copies of the 1916
[Proclamation of the Irish Republic](/wiki/Proclamation_of_the_Irish_Republic
"Proclamation of the Irish Republic"). This proclamation was read by [Patrick
Pearse](/wiki/Patrick_Pearse "Patrick Pearse") near the General Post Office on
24 April 1916. Visitors may also view the [Trinity College
harp](/wiki/Trinity_College_harp "Trinity College harp") (also known as the
"[Brian Boru harp](/wiki/Brian_Boru_harp "Brian Boru harp")") in The Long Room
that is the oldest of its kind in Ireland dating back to the 15th century. The
harp is made out of oak and willow and includes 29 brass strings.[5]

### In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Trinity_College_Library&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: In popular culture")]

The [Jedi](/wiki/Jedi "Jedi") archives of the Jedi Temple in the movie _[Star
Wars: Episode II – Attack of the
Clones](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_%E2%80%93_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars:
Episode II – Attack of the Clones")_ bear a startling resemblance to the Long
Room of the Trinity College Library. This resemblance resulted in controversy
as permission had not been sought to use the building's likeness in the film.
However, [Lucasfilm](/wiki/Lucasfilm "Lucasfilm") denied that the Long Room
was the basis for the Jedi archives, and officials from Trinity College
Library decided not to take any legal action.[6][7]
